curriculumAlignment.outcomeDescription: Properties of the different states of matter can be explained in terms of the motion and arrangement of particles

keyConcepts.name: Three states of matter
keyConcepts.description: Solids, liquids, and gases as fundamental states with distinct observable properties

keyConcepts.name: Particle model of matter
keyConcepts.description: All matter is made of tiny particles (atoms/molecules) that are too small to see

keyConcepts.name: Particle arrangement in solids
keyConcepts.description: Particles in solids are closely packed in fixed positions, held by strong forces

keyConcepts.name: Particle arrangement in liquids
keyConcepts.description: Particles in liquids are close together but can move past each other

keyConcepts.name: Particle arrangement in gases
keyConcepts.description: Particles in gases are far apart, move rapidly, and fill their container

keyConcepts.name: Particle motion and energy
keyConcepts.description: Particles are always moving; higher temperature means faster particle motion

keyConcepts.name: Changes of state
keyConcepts.description: Melting, freezing, boiling, condensation, sublimation as energy-driven processes

keyConcepts.name: Diffusion
keyConcepts.description: Particles spread from high to low concentration due to random motion

keyConcepts.name: Energy and state changes
keyConcepts.description: Energy is absorbed during melting/boiling and released during freezing/condensation

keyConcepts.name: Kinetic theory fundamentals
keyConcepts.description: Temperature is a measure of average kinetic energy of particles

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Particles in a solid don't move at all
commonMisconceptions.correction: Particles in solids vibrate in fixed positions - they have kinetic energy but cannot change places

commonMisconceptions.misconception: When a solid is heated, the particles get bigger
commonMisconceptions.correction: Particles stay the same size; they vibrate more and take up more space (thermal expansion)

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Liquids are halfway between solids and gases in particle spacing
commonMisconceptions.correction: Particles in liquids are actually close together (like solids), but can move and change places

commonMisconceptions.misconception: There is air between particles in matter
commonMisconceptions.correction: The space between particles is empty (vacuum) - not filled with air

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Particles have the same properties as the bulk substance (gold atoms are shiny, water molecules are wet)
commonMisconceptions.correction: Macroscopic properties emerge from particle interactions - individual particles don't have these properties

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Melting and dissolving are the same process
commonMisconceptions.correction: Melting is a physical change of state (solid to liquid); dissolving is mixing with a solvent

commonMisconceptions.misconception: When a solid melts, particles 'pop' or disappear
commonMisconceptions.correction: Particles remain; they gain energy and break free from fixed positions to move around

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Gas is not really matter / gases have no mass
commonMisconceptions.correction: Gases are matter - they have mass and take up space, just spread out more

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Water molecules change during phase changes (different molecules in ice vs steam)
commonMisconceptions.correction: The same H2O molecules exist in all three states - only their arrangement and energy changes

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Cold makes particles stop moving completely
commonMisconceptions.correction: Particles always have some motion above absolute zero (-273°C); cold only slows them down

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Ice cream melting on a hot day
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Why does ice cream melt faster outside than in the freezer?
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Summer beach trips, hot Australian climate

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Steam rising from a hot shower
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Where does the steam go when it disappears into the air?
Why does the mirror fog up and then clear again?
Where does dew come from if it didn't rain overnight?

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Smell of perfume spreading across a room
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: How can you smell perfume from across the room without any wind?
What makes popcorn 'pop' - and why doesn't all corn do this?

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Deflated football on a cold morning
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Why does a football seem flat on a cold morning but fine by lunchtime?
Most substances sink when solid - why does ice float?
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Drinks with ice, icebergs in documentaries

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Why does dry ice skip the liquid stage and go straight to gas?

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Cooking - butter melting in a pan
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Why does butter melt at room temperature but chocolate doesn't?

scaffoldingSequence.name: Activate Prior Knowledge
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Observable properties of solids, liquids, gases

scaffoldingSequence.name: Introduce Particle Model
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Matter is made of particles; basic arrangement differences

scaffoldingSequence.name: Challenge Misconceptions
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Particle motion, state changes, energy connection

scaffoldingSequence.name: Extend and Apply
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Kinetic theory, complex applications, unusual cases

cognitiveLoadNotes: Introduce particle model visually before abstract descriptions (Mayer's multimedia principle)
Use animations/simulations to show particle motion - reduces need for mental visualization
Keep diagrams and explanations spatially close (contiguity principle)
Build from familiar macroscopic observations before introducing particle explanations
engagementStrategies: Start with everyday examples (ice, water, steam) before scientific terminology
Allow predictions before explanations - creates curiosity gap
Use anomalies to spark interest (Why does ice float? Why does dry ice skip liquid?)
Connect to cooking and food science for relevance
motivationFactors: Connect to cooking and kitchen science
Link to weather phenomena and seasons
Relate to sports (ball pressure, swimming pools)
Use Australian context (hot climate, beach culture)
desirableDifficulties: Interleave solid/liquid/gas comparisons rather than blocking
Include retrieval practice questions that require recalling earlier concepts
Vary question contexts to promote transfer
testingEffectOpportunities: Low-stakes quizzes after each concept cluster

questionDesignGuidelines.mcqDistractorStrategy: Use documented misconceptions as distractors (e.g., 'particles get bigger when heated')
questionDesignGuidelines.shortAnswerFocus: Require particle-level explanations for macroscopic observations
questionDesignGuidelines.diagramQuestions: Include particle arrangement diagrams for interpretation and prediction
questionDesignGuidelines.calculationOpportunities: Limited at Year 8 - focus on qualitative understanding
questionDesignGuidelines.realWorldApplication: At least 40% of questions should use real-world contexts

supportStrategies: Break multi-step reasoning into guided questions
extensionOpportunities: Research absolute zero and Bose-Einstein condensates
